name: Pipestone National Monument
description: For over 3,000 years, Indigenous people have quarried the red stone at this site to make pipes used in prayer and ceremony - a tradition that continues to this day and makes this site sacred to many people.
shortDescription: For over 3,000 years, Indigenous people have quarried the red stone at this site to make pipes used in prayer and ceremony - a tradition that continues to this day and makes this site sacred to many p...

operatingHours.description: The grounds are open 24 hours a day year-round so that visitors may walk the 3/4-mile Circle Trail at any time.

climate.weatherDescription: Weather varies seasonally from warm and humid in the summer to cold and snowy in the winter. Visitors should be prepared for seasonal weather and for rapidly-changing conditions.

images.title: Sioux Quartzite Cliffs
images.altText: Pink wall of rock next to path and grass
images.caption: The outcroppings along the trail are a surprise to many visitors expecting a flat prairie

images.title: Tallgrass Prairie
images.altText: Purple and yellow wildflowers in a field of tall grass
images.caption: The tallgrass prairie is an explosion of color spring through fall

images.title: Snowshoeing the Circle Trail
images.altText: A couple outside in snowshoes smiling at the camera
images.caption: Snowshoeing is available for free after January 1st

images.title: Pulling Pipestone
images.altText: A sheet of stone being taken off a thick slab of stone in a quarry pit
images.caption: It can take months or even years to reach the pipestone layer in a quarry pit.

images.title: Jr. Ranger Camp Programs
images.altText: A woman standing next to a little girl helping her make a clay pot
images.caption: Kids have opportunities throughout the summer for hands-on activities

images.title: Breaking Through
images.altText: A man in a quarry pit swings a hammer as a woman watches
images.caption: Quarriers must break through over 6 feet of quartzite to reach the pipestone layer

images.title: Learning to Carve Pipestone
images.altText: A man watches over a woman as she saws a piece of stone
images.caption: Travis Erickson teaches new carver, Jessica Arkeketa, how to make a pipe

images.title: Winnewissa Falls in Winter
images.altText: A waterfall partially surrounded by ice
images.caption: Winnewissa Falls is a favorite spot for visitors all year long

images.title: Teaching the Next Generation
images.altText: A man works with tools in a quarry as kids watch
images.caption: Quarrier and carver Francis Eastman teaches Indigenous youth how to quarry

images.title: Aaron Prim Breaking Through Quartzite
images.altText: A man in a quarry pit holding a sledge hammer
images.caption: Quarrier Aaron Prim working his way through 6 feet of quartzite to reach pipestone
